bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to H. Carter Redd, December 9, 1947

div1.p: Hench writes to Redd about Carter's influence on Lazear and Reed in relation to the mosquito theory of yellow fever transmission. He seeks Carter correspondence to document this influence, and believes Lazear was more supportive of the mosquito theory than Reed, who intended to fully test the bacterial theory first.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to H. Carter Redd, December 9, 1947
div1.opener:
December 9, 1947
Mr. H. Carter Redd
1104 Travelers Building
Richmond, Virginia
My dear Mr. Redd:
div1.p:
Your letter addressed to me at the University of Virginia has been
forwarded to me here. I have just returned from our eastern trip. I am de-
lighted to receive your letter. I am trying to write up the whole story of
the conquest of yellow fever and of those many people who helped Walter Reed.

One of the points which I have not been able to settle yet to my
satisfaction concerns the help which Henry Rose Carter gave to the Yellow
Fever Board. I have no little time trying to trace some direct correspondence
between Reed and Carter or Lazear and Carter and until your letter arrived I
had found nothing.

By separate post, I am sending you a reprint and as you read it,
I think you will see it has been my impression that although Reed had un-
doubtedly decided to investigate the mosquito theory, it was to be done
“in due time” and after they had gotten rid of the bacterial theory.
Lazear apparently in the early days believed in the mosquito theory much more
strongly than did Reed. He couldn't stand the delay and was impatient to
get going on the mosquito theory, as a letter to his wife at that time showed.
Because of Lazear's greater interest, I have suspected that Lazear was the first
convert to Carter's work, and I have wondered whether Carter and Lazear had any
correspondence in the spring and early summer of 1900. I have tried to find out
whether Carter brought his own work to Reed's attention; or whether Lazear brought
Carter's work to Reed's attention. Please do not think that I am in any way
trying to belittle the overwhelming importance of Reed's work, I am just trying
to get the story in order.

I have visited in recent years most of the survivors of these experi-
ments and have had innumerable conversations with General Kean and General
Truby and others. The points mentioned above have not so far been settled and
I would appreciate greatly your further help in the matter.

I am a member of the Board of Managers of the Walter Reed Memorial
Association, of which Admiral Stitt is also a member. As you already know,
he married Laura Carter, the daughter of Henry Rose Carter. I have been
anxious to locate relatives of Doctor Carter who might have information or
correspondence mentioned above, but so far I have not been able to find where
these relatives live. Last week, I had hoped to see Admiral Stitt at our meeting
but he was ill and did not attend. Could you give me the addresses of Doctor
Carter's close relatives. Am I correct in assuming from your name, that you
are also a relative? I appreciate greatly indeed your kindness in writing to me.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
